docs.abstract: Trump administration officials are trying to pressure Beijing to ease trade restrictions before the president and his counterpart meet this week.
docs.snippet: Trump administration officials are trying to pressure Beijing to ease trade restrictions before the president and his counterpart meet this week.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration reiterated on Wednesday its intention to raise tariffs on cars made in China, a move aimed at pressuring Beijing into easing trade restrictions on American companies ahead of President Trump’s meeting with President Xi Jinping of China this week.

headline.main: U.S. Stresses Plan to Raise Tariffs on Chinese Cars

byline.original: By Alan Rappeport and Glenn Thrush

docs.abstract: At a hearing in London, officials from nine countries criticized the social network and said they planned to release internal Facebook documents soon.
docs.snippet: At a hearing in London, officials from nine countries criticized the social network and said they planned to release internal Facebook documents soon.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Officials from nine countries examining Facebook’s business practices have spent weeks trying to get the company’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, to face questions at a hearing.

headline.main: A Hot Seat for Facebook, an Empty Chair for Zuckerberg and a Vow to Share Secret Files
headline.print_headline: Zuckerberg Snubs a Multinational Inquiry Into Facebook’s Practices

docs.abstract: A simple rule that bolsters the banking system — “know your customer” — could help combat fake news and hate speech online if companies like Facebook and Twitter embraced it.
docs.snippet: A simple rule that bolsters the banking system — “know your customer” — could help combat fake news and hate speech online if companies like Facebook and Twitter embraced it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Exactly a year ago, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, testified before Congress and apologized for his company’s role in enabling “fake news, foreign interference in elections and hate speech.”

headline.main: To Purge Some of Social Media’s Ugliness, an Unlikely Lesson From Wall St.
headline.print_headline: Good Advice From Banks To Facebook

docs.abstract: New research from Microsoft says that far fewer people have broadband internet access than government statistics have shown.
docs.snippet: New research from Microsoft says that far fewer people have broadband internet access than government statistics have shown.
docs.lead_paragraph: Ferry County in northeastern Washington spans more than 2,200 square miles of mostly forestland, rivers and lakes. And according to the Federal Communications Commission, everyone in the sprawling county has access to broadband internet.

headline.main: Digital Divide Is Wider Than We Think, Study Says

docs.abstract: With 148 million subscribers and a value of $157 billion, Netflix is the leader in streaming. But Hulu, now controlled by Disney, has something Netflix doesn’t: ads. And they are worth a lot.
docs.snippet: With 148 million subscribers and a value of $157 billion, Netflix is the leader in streaming. But Hulu, now controlled by Disney, has something Netflix doesn’t: ads. And they are worth a lot.

headline.main: As Netflix Contends With More Rivals, Hulu Stands Out
headline.print_headline: Netflix Has Many Rivals, But Hulu Stands Apart

docs.abstract: There are risks when filing criminal charges against banks, but how else to deter wrongdoing on Wall Street?
docs.snippet: There are risks when filing criminal charges against banks, but how else to deter wrongdoing on Wall Street?
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: Goldman’s Malaysian Scandal Revives the ‘Too Big to Jail’ Debate

docs.abstract: The Fed is widely expected to raise rates at the conclusion of its two-day meeting on Wednesday. But all eyes are on what happens next.
docs.snippet: The Fed is widely expected to raise rates at the conclusion of its two-day meeting on Wednesday. But all eyes are on what happens next.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise interest rates at its final meeting of the year. Amid mounting worries about the economic outlook for 2019, the Fed is also expected to emphasize that future rate hikes will depend on the continued strength of the domestic economy.

headline.main: What to Watch Ahead of the Fed Meeting

docs.abstract: In Geneva, the United States faced accusations that Trump trade policies are undermining the global economy. China portrayed itself as the voice of reason.
docs.snippet: In Geneva, the United States faced accusations that Trump trade policies are undermining the global economy. China portrayed itself as the voice of reason.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The Americans accused the Chinese of being modern-day mercantilists who steal intellectual property. The Europeans accused the Americans of provoking a crisis in the world trading system, threatening the global economy.

headline.main: Global Trade Tensions Boil Over at Staid W.T.O. Forum
headline.print_headline: U.S. Trade Moves Attacked At Staid W.T.O. Assembly

docs.abstract: Mortgage lenders are again promoting more complicated loans, which offer benefits for wealthy borrowers but come with big drawbacks.
docs.snippet: Mortgage lenders are again promoting more complicated loans, which offer benefits for wealthy borrowers but come with big drawbacks.
docs.lead_paragraph: Interest rates have started to rise, and the housing market is cooling off, a combination that is putting a squeeze on mortgage lenders. Now, some of them are turning to more complicated loans, a remnant of the last housing boom, to bolster their business.

headline.main: Risky Home Loans Are Making a Comeback. Are They Right for You?
headline.print_headline: The Return of the Risky Loan

docs.abstract: The jailing of Carlos Ghosn and Greg Kelly exposed stark differences in how crimes are pursued and suspects are handled in Japan and in Western democracies.
docs.snippet: The jailing of Carlos Ghosn and Greg Kelly exposed stark differences in how crimes are pursued and suspects are handled in Japan and in Western democracies.
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Five months ago, Carlos Ghosn, a multimillionaire executive credited with reviving Nissan Motors, hosted the wedding of his daughter Caroline on Naoshima, a rarefied island enclave of art and sculpture. The celebration began with the cracking open of a barrel of sake, an elegant and traditional way in Japan to toast good fortune.

headline.main: Japanese Justice Faces Scrutiny in Case of Nissan Chief and U.S. Board Member
headline.print_headline: Nissan Case Shows Divide Over Justice

byline.original: By Motoko Rich and Jack Ewing
